bargain.translation[0].definitions[0].de: something you buy cheaply or for less than its usual price
bargain.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: There are no bargains in the clothes shops at the moment.
It’s an attractive little home, and I think it’s a bargain.
That second-hand table was a real bargain.
Good watches don't come at bargain prices.
Bargain hunters (=people looking for things to buy at low prices) queued outside the store for hours.
bargain.translation[0].definitions[1].de: an agreement, made between two people or groups, to do something in return for something else
bargain.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: I’ve kept my side of the bargain and I expect you to keep yours.
Management and unions have struck a bargain over wage increases.
bargain.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: In the market you can sometimes pick up a real bargain.
The house they bought was an amazing bargain.
She began looking for bargains at car boot sales.
Everyone likes to think they are getting a bargain.
Investors may be able to find some bargains this year.
You can often pick up a bargain at an auction.
The Regency hotel is offering off-season bargains.
In the sales you can get a fully fitted kitchen at a bargain price.
This remains a bargain buy at £3.99.
Bargain hunters queued for hours before the store opened.
They're off to do some bargain hunting at the January sales.
Everything is reduced to clear in the bargain basement!
bargain.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to discuss the conditions of a sale, agreement etc, for example to try and get a lower price
bargain.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: They bargained over the level of wages.
bargain.translation[2].definitions[0].de: something you buy cheaply or for less than the usual price
bargain.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: The company’s shares are a bargain at the current level.
He made a lot of money by buying houses at bargain prices and reselling them.
bargain.translation[2].definitions[1].de: an agreement between two people or groups to do something in return for something else
bargain.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: Management and unions have managed to strike a bargain whereby unions have accepted more flexible working in return for better pay.
Football is important to Sky TV, and the clubs will now try todrive a hard bargain (=make a bargaining agreement very much to their advantage) on future TV rights.
bargain.translation[2].definitions[2].de: an occasion when particular shares, bonds etc are bought or sold on a financial market. The number of bargains in a particular period of time is one measurement of the level of economic activity
bargain.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: In government securities, the number of bargains per day has averaged nearly 3,300.
bargain.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to discuss the conditions of a sale, agreement etc in order to get the greatest advantage for yourself
